column1: In 2021, will total fire activity in the Amazon exceed the 2020 total count?
column6: ['Environment']
19.22 per cent less fire activity than in 2020, as of 28 December 2021.
Relaxed environmental controls and increased drought

Seems incredibly unlikely at this point.

http://www.globalfiredata.org/regional.html#amazon As of now all regions in Brazil are reporting much higher rates, it seemed that at the beggining of the year something was taking place that showed slow growth and suddlenly the last numbers are accumulatively much higher.

December generally sees slow increase in fires, with only two years in the last 18 seeing disproportionate fire activity in December such that they overtook another year's total - and both of them were on a steeper trajectory already than 2021.
Less doctoring of data thanks to hightened environmental concerns
Unprecedented growth in count is required from this point to exceed 2020 count
Too unlikely by now.
The curve flattens after Oct each year, unlikely for 2021 to catch up at this moment.

Using data from 11/20 I project EOM totals of ~257k (+/- about 10%) and EOY totals of ~268k +/- 11k. At this point there would have to an increase of > 50k fires for 2021 to reach the total fire-count of 2020. Just doesn't seem plausible to me. Therefore I am joining @belikewater and others in the 0% bucket.
It would be unprecedented in the data for the number of fires to grow enough in the time remaining for 2021 to have more fires than 2020.

Nov 13 data totals are 250,233. Extrapolating out to the EOM, I again forecast a total of ~259k +/-10% and EOY totals of ~270k +/- 10%. Now my forecasts are starting to converge within 2 SDs. Pushing my probability down with just a few points left for the far outside chance something odd occurs.

https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/fires-brazilian-amazon-retreat-september-2021-09-30/ https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/amazon-fires-surge-anew-brazil-cleared-forest-burns-2021-09-03/ https://www.statista.com/statistics/1044328/number-wildfires-legal-amazon/
Passage of time.

Using Nov totals of 246,040, I'm forecasting EOM totals of ~259k +/-10% and EOY totals of 270k +/- 10%. Unless something extraordinary occurs, it appears extremely (~10% or less) unlikely that 2021 will exceed 2020 values. Am adjusting probability accordingly.
Yeah, it's actually a pretty big gap.
Increasing the probability somewhat, but not too far because similarly large gaps have been closed before the end of the year before, sometimes right up to the end.

Predicted End of Oct totals of ~250k +/- 10%. Totals as of Oct 30th were 241k, so very close. Now projecting EOY totals of ~281k +/-10%, so on track so far. Am reducing my probability to reflect the data to date.

Based on 10/19/21 results I am forecasting EOM total of ~250k +/- 10%. Using my Oct linear model this implies an EOY total of ~289k +/-18k. Using a combined log normal and normal probability model I get an implied prob (2021 > 2020) = 3.9%. Assuming that I am being a bit aggressive with my modeling, I've moved to aggregating with a few selected peers from the crowd. After this I end up around 11% for my final forecast.

Using 10/11/21 totals I project an end of Oct total of ~250k +/- 10% and an EOY value of 292k [255k, 328k]. Revised probability of 2021 being greater than 2020 is down to 5.3%. Taking geometric mean of my 4Cast and the crowd get ~16% as my final estimate.

Going down 10 points due to @LokiOdinevich's recent forecast and rationale... but not just his recent forecast but his overall perspective on this throughout the months. I think you @LokiOdinevich had a great grasp on the topic at hand! #OntheRightSideofMaybe
Now very unlikely. Looking at the graph numbers, the numbers are substantially below, and we haven't seen large increases at th is point in the year in the past.
Laplace and standard deviation based - after selecting certain years.

Last estimated that end of Sept #s would be approx ~194k. Actual results was 196,578 so not bad. Projecting end of October totals to be approx ~254k +/- 10% and EOY totals to be ~293k [258k, 331k] 95% CLimits. Using a normal approximation, I get the probability of 2021 >= 2020 (ie, 322,222 k) = 6%. Borrowing an idea from a prior @LokiOdinevich posting, I will calculate a mean using my estimate and the crowd, to ensure that I'm not getting too far ahead of myself to obtain: geometric mean(0.06, 0.50) ~ 18%.
Am I going crazy? Perhaps I'm looking at the wrong graph?
Wait. If I'm not mistaken, 20
(oops)

Using 9/26 data (185,525) and linear extrapolation have and end of Sept estimate of ~194k. Using this with monte-carlo generalized regression model obtain an EOY estimate of 277k with 95% CL [224k, 333k]. Normal approximation implies a probability of about 7% exceeding 2020 numbers. Aggregating with prior, new forecast, and peers (weighted Logits) results in a final 22%

> ## September 26th > fires2021Now <- 182848 > dataNow <- c(285205, 395735, 427896, 258665, 371511, 164904, 95693, 381749, 122439, 187179, 97659 , 125899, 159380, 192896, 212913, 140216, 229144, 211703) > analyzeData(dataNow, fires2021Now) Lower bound (75%): 137136 Upper bound (125%): 228560 Years within bounds: 2008 2012 2015 2016 2017 2018 2020 # Fires on those years now: 164904 187179 159380 192896 212913 140216 211703 # Fires on those years at end of year: 281387 270555 307647 272997 316986 197049 322222 Greater than 2020? FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE Implied probability (counting 2020 as 1/2 of a year): 0.07142857 Probability weighing the crowd 50/50: (0.07142857+0.51)/2 = 0.2907143

Based on 9/23/21 count data am projecting Sept total of about 194k and EOY median estimate of approx 280k +/- 10%. Regression of September totals vs EOY totals have an R-Square value of 0.97. Unless something quite unusual occurs, 2021 forecast to end below 2020 EOY, so lowering my probability further.

Lowering my probability based on extrapolated end of September total numbers (~189k +/- 10%). Using a linear monte-carlo model and accounting for error in both the regression parameters and the RMSE residual error, I get a median end of year forecast of ~272k fires with a 95% CI of 219k to 326k. Will update further with new data.

I've been overconfident on both sides of YES and NO, but I think the evidence now is that after September, the rate slows, which is a strong trend (assumption). So therefore, I think it's safe to say this is unlikely.

Running new monte-carlo estimation model. Based on results from Sept 15th, I'm estimating a total of approximately 190k by the end of the month +/- about 10%. This is lower than I originally expected. Am therefore down-weighting my end of year probability a few points.
Been a long day and I updated the wrong question. This 64% was intended for a separate question. This is unacceptable. ERROR forecast.
Currently still tracking below 2020 numbers for the same time period. Adjusting down slightly based on this.

Total fire count as of 8/26/21 was 121,465. Extrapolating out to the end of the months suggests the total by end of August reaching 135k (+/- error). Using two different models I show an increased chance of 2021 exceeding 2020. Consequently, I am increasing my probability for exceedance to 65% and will continue to adjust upwards as needed.

So far the numbers are tracking the median closely. Am revising my estimate accordingly.

I changed my mind because the year-long average so far and the past week's average are not consistent with the argument that 2020 will be a quieter year. In the last week, the exponential rate has been 3x greater for 2021 than the same period of time in 2020. The linear rate has been 1.6x greater for this same time comparison. An analagous year to 2020 would be 2017 in that both ended their respective years with similar totals. At this time in 2017, the exponential growth rate was approximately 10%. The same period of time in 2021, was between 9% and 10%. So because at the top of the year so far in 2021 totals have been—with a greater growth likely ahead—are consistent with 2020's cousin year 2017 and currently beating 2020, I upgrade my probabilities.

Brazil is about to enforce a law to retroactively legalize 2020's land-grabbing by farmers. Experts forecast dire consequences with respect to the scope of land-grabbing in the future. However, in Germany for example the largest retailer chains which nearly dominate the complete domestic market are said to threaten Brazil with a complete stop of supply chains/boycott, if the draft becomes law... https://www.spiegel.de/wirtschaft/unternehmen/rinder-statt-regenwald-in-brasilien-aldi-lidl-und-co-erwaegen-boykott-a-ac9a2809-d68c-4a7b-95ff-5959b7ed0255

So far the current monthly cumulative numbers are tracking the median results. Using both Log and Nml distribution assumptions, I get less than 30% chance of exceeding the 2020 results. Only time will tell. Will adjust forecast accordingly as new data is available.

I'm still cautious that the rate has been higher in 2021 so far than in 2020, although lately the rate has slowed below 2020's rate. By rate I mean divide the new figure by an old figure and compare each year's result.

But, 2020 was the driest year in more than 20 years. There was 9.5% more deforestation in 2020 than in 2019, but there were 27% more fires, at least in part because 2020 was drier. The Amazon is increasingly facing droughts. But will this year be as dry as last year?
On second thought, what's going to stop even more fires being set this year than last year?

Bolsonaro just promised to do more to protect the Amazon but has already backtracked. But: "Later this year, if Amazon fires are as bad or worse than in 2019 and 2020, Brazilian agricultural exports could face an EU and international boycott, which might hurt sales, though no one yet knows how China, Brazil’s largest commodities customer, and chief Brazilian soy buyer, will respond." https://news.mongabay.com/2021/04/bolsonaro-abandons-enhanced-amazon-commitment-same-day-he-makes-it/
It's currently about half of last year's fire activity.

At this point in time, fire activity reported so far this year is roughly 55% of the activity in 2020 at the same date, however representing early season and thus only less than 5% of the total activity of an average full year. Most deforestation obviously happening in August, Spetember, October, it could depend on demand for certain crops that grow well on soil and under climate conditions of the Amazon region, and 2021 further price development on world markets, such as soy, as profits from extended farming are a key incentive for land-grabbing and land reclamation. There have been years with a slow start which nevertheless ended at the top of the list (e.g. 2007), and there have been years with a fast pace of destruction initially that ended with a mediocre number of fire activity (such as 2016).

I assume that after a year where the year previous had less fires, the next year will see a lower number of fires because there is not enough land to burn as the forest is still regrowing. Now with the higher than average rainfall forecast this year because of la nina, it is possible that a regrowth will in fact occur, but it may not be substantial enough. On the other hand, with la nina, that could mean a lower threat of wildfires like weather experts at AccuWeather forecast for South America this la nina season. I will weight their opinion more. There are other factors I looked at like el nino cycles and la nina cycles and compared to the historical wildfire graph to find correlations. I cannot articulate them well enough here but I do believe they are strongly correlated and that this current situation supports a hypothesis of NO - at least for this year.

Global warming continues. Rainfall continues to slow. People in Brazil continue to light the Amazon on fire. All these problems are getting worse. Unless random chance spares the Amazon, there will be increased fire.

To make this prediction, I had to break this down into at least two questions. What factors are causing the Amazon to burn so much, and will those factors increase or decrease within the next year? What has been the rising fire trend in these forests? For the first question, I found a helpful site: https://earthsky.org/earth/amazon-rainforest-fires-burning-4-reasons-why. Here, they list 3, not 4 (as advertised in the title) main reasons why it is burning. Increased farming in the rainforest, which causes deforestation, infrastructure development and deforestation due to silence on the part of Bolsonaro, and road choked streams. These factors are only going to increase, due to the growing population of Brazil, Bolsonaro’s unwillingness to spend money on saving the environment and using it for his benefit, and increasing infrastructure including roads. Segments of forests that have burned already, constitute only a small fraction of the total acreage of Amazonian rainforests, therefore there is still a lot more that could burn in the fire season (June-November) of next year. The second question was answered by https://www.globalfiredata.org/updates.html, which has month to month fire data. DUe to raising trends in deforestation which has a direct correlation to fires, I predict that 2021 will have an increased chance of meeting and or exceeding the 2020 fire count. Chance of meeting the 2020 fire count: 100%. Chance of exceeding the fire count: 50%. = 75% chance.
4/8 Update: I was looking at the wrong data.

Deforestation is propelling the Amazon towards a tipping point, beyond which it will gradually transform into a semi-arid savanna. If the deforestation of the rainforest continues past a threshold of 20-25 per cent total deforestation, multiple positive feedback loops will spark the desertification of the Amazon Basin.

Bolsonero's activation of the armed forces to prevent deforestation which is likely to continue in '21 due to the environmental agencies' inabilities to increase manpower from COVID/economy) and drought (likely to continue due to La Nina weather patterns continuing, Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation combining with climate change to raise water temperatures).

My estimation is based on a few factors: - the 6-mo. average sea surface temperatures (SST) 12-mo. prior to the current fire season (June - Nov.) - the 6-mo. average sea surface temperatures (SST) 6-mo. prior to the current fire season (June - Nov.) - the political climate of Brazil regarding the Amazon rain forest, particularly with regard to President Bolsonaro

There are two competing influences on the level of fires in 2021. One is political and depends on how powerful Bolsonaro is in the rest of his term. With Biden as US President, he will have less backing for his ecological vandalism. The Second is climatic and with a moderate to strong La Niña in progress for the start of the year leading to flooding in the Amazon basin the odds are that there will be less burning than in 2020.

Deforestation fires account for >40% of fires in the southern Amazon (See link #1 below from globalfiredata.org) and this is not expected to decrease. This, coupled with the correlation made (in an article posted May 22nd on the same website below) to the rise in fires with the rise in ocean temperatures, that is likely to continue to increase with global warming, makes me believe the number and intensity of fires in 2021 should increase. Without significant advocacy or enforceable governmental restriction, I don't see this changing, and potentially exceeding 2005 numbers (when the El' Nino drought caused significant increases in fires). Interestingly, the pattern of droughts in the rainforest has occurred in 2005, 2010, and 2015/16, which puts the course for additional drought activity patterned for 2020/21. Research has found that "... when two areas in the Atlantic Ocean which are situated north and south of each other start to go out of phase – that is when temperatures are rising in one, but decreasing in the other – the Amazon is likely to experience a severe drought within 1-1.5 years." (from TiPES article #2). Furthermore, as noted in an EcoWatch study, "Faced with the effects of climate change, there is a risk that the Northern Hemisphere will heat up faster than the South, which would stimulate the occurrence of the Atlantic dipole and lead to a more intense frequency of droughts in the Amazon." (See EcoWatch article #3). This provides a general rationale for the general shift in unfavorable forces that can lead to greater potential for drought and continued increase in the future Amazonian fire risk.

La Nina weather system increases fire risk. Global Warming increases fire risk. Human disturbance increases fire risk - all rising this past year/season.

Frequency matching on the data from 2003 to 2019 gives %35 if the fires in 2020 are extrapolated to about 326k, fitting a normal distribution to the data from 2011 to 2020 gives %11 odds, and incorporating a linear trend in the data from 2011 to 2020 (p = 0.08 on beta) gives about %44. The linear trend is not statistically significant at a 0.05 level (and I have a prior belief that the linear trend shouldn't be large, even if it's there) and the early 2000s data looks unrepresentative, so I give them lower weights (1/4 each) in a geometric mean. This gives about %20.77, rounded up to %21.
Thanks @ThomasBass and @Tinned_Tuna. I'm going to split the difference between your forecasts as my starting point.
I'm going to take @ThomasBass data from https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1186205, throw out everything before 2011, and go from there.

Several climate scientists are predicting that the Amazon rainforest is reaching a tipping point, in which, in the next 15 to 20 years, it will no longer produce enough rain to sustain itself and begin to dry out. In addition to that, the increased deforestation has led to worse outcomes for the forest overall; Increased development and deforestation has contributed an increasing number of fires over time. Lastly, La Nina may make the fires particularly worse than 2020. “Cooling of the eastern Pacific due to the developing La Niña will likely result in drier and warmer-than-normal conditions from western Colombia, Ecuador and Peru,” said Nicholls, AccuWeather's lead international forecaster. “Drought conditions can develop in these areas.” This confluence of factors leads to the likelihood that the total fire activity in the Amazon in 2021 will exceed 2020.
Most of the 2020 increment due to the fires in Mato Grosso. 15% of the state was scorched, a larger percent of forest/jungle land. Irregular cattle activity had plenty to do with the fires.

Trends suggest that in 2021 fire activity in the Amazon will exceed that of 2020. By September 2020 the count had already surpassed 2019. Additionally, deforestation continues in key regions of the Amazon, with little stop in sight. Climate change, specifically sea surface temperatures, continue to rise and I predict this will not change in 2021.
Guessing probably no as a result of continuing La Nina, but with low confidence.
With climate change, the wildfire situation will continue to get worse.

The president of Brazil has no intention of acting on the concerns of environmentalists. Brazil currently ranks 3rd in number of covid cases world wide. The economic cost of the virus is badly impacting the Brazilian economy, which means the government will be under great pressure to stimulate the economy at all costs. Agricultural production will in particular see a major push, which in return is responsible for a lot of the forest fires we see in the Amazon. Until there is a regime change, or major international sanctions, the government will continue to ignore forest fires that are being ignited by people wanting more land for agricultural production.
